resources.string: Global Distribution Map of Fire Ant Mounds

Red Imported Fire Ant

The Red Imported Fire Ant (also known in shorthand as the RIFA) is an invasive species of ant that originates from central South America, mainly in Brazil. RIFA can be found all across the world at this point, including in such varied places such as Antigua and Barbuda, Bahamas, the British and U.S. Virgin Islands, Cayman Islands, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan, the United States, New Zealand, China, Trinidad and Tobago, and the Turks and Caicos Islands. Only in China and New Zealand have there been successful eradication programs of the RIFA so far.

Origination in the U.S.

 The RIFA first appeared in the U.S. from (an estimated) 1933-1945 in ports of Mobile, Alabama. It has been theorized that ships that contained cargo from Brazil introduced the RIFA to the U.S. during this time period. Since that time, the RIFA has spread across much of the Southeastern U.S.. States that have been invaded and have permanent colony establishment include Alabama, Arkansas, California, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Maryland, Mississippi, New Mexico, North Carolina, South Carolina, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Texas, and Virginia. RIFA have not spread beyond the Southeastern U.S. because they cannot survive the cold temperatures of winter that many parts of the U.S. experience.

 Identification

RIFA are insects, which invertebrates that have a chitinous exoskeleton, a three part body (head, thorax and abdomen), six legs, compound eyes and one pair of antennae. RIFA colonies consist of a queen or queens (the presence of multiple queens in a colony is called polygyny), workers, brood and eggs. RIFA workers can range from 2.4 to 6 mm in length and all workers have a stinger at the end of their body (this location on the body is called the gaster). When one stings you, the compound they inject contains formic acid, which usually causes a white pustule to form where the sting happened. RIFA typically have red bodies with a black gaster and have two ten-segmented antennae. All workers are sterile females.

Colony Lifecycle

RIFA colonies tend to spread through mating flights in the summer months, which can involve thousands of queens flying up high into the air to mate. After mating occurs, RIFA queens find a new, suitable spot to set up a new colony. Occasionally, more than one queen will set up a colony together. After finding a suitable site, the queen will break off her wings and burrow into soil in order to start a mound. Within 24 hours of the original mating, fire ant queens will start to lay eggs. 8 to 10 eggs are usually laid in these first 24 hours. The queen uses her (useless) wing muscles in order to sustain her first batch of eggs and brood. When the first brood that mature are known as minims. These minims burrow out of the chamber, forage for food and help feed the queen and the new eggs and brood the queen is constantly laying and tending to. Construction of the mound beings here also. After just one month, larger workers start to appear and a mound is now clearly visible. After just six months, several thousand workers populate the mound.

 Biology

Workers eat dead animals, including insects, earthworms and vertebrates. RIFA are notoriously known to not be picky about what they eat as they will eat anything that contain sugars, proteins and fats.
Question 1: What is the scientific name for the red fire ant species that has invaded most of the Southeastern United States?\n
Question 2: An acronym that is associated with the red fire ant is RIFA. What does the acronym RIFA mean?\n
Question 3: What country is the red fire ant native to (ie. what country was it accidentally imported from in the 1930s to the United States)?\n
Question 4: What entity, element or living being has helped the red fire ant spread over the widest global area in the last 80 years?\n
Question 5: Multiple fire ant queens can start and cohabitat in a single colony. True or false? If true, indicate what this behavior is called. If false, indicate what this behavior is called.\n
Question 6: Where was the red fire ant (accidentally) first introduced to the United States? Hint: It is a city that has a port.\n
Question 7: What method has been proven most effective and safe (for humans and the environment) in eliminating fire ant colonies?\n

Question 8: What is the name of the chemical compound that the red fire ant releases if it stings an animal or a human? The compound can cause a white pustule on the skin to form (it is usually very itchy) or in more severe cases, a severe allergic reaction (chest pains, nausea, even a coma).\n
Question 9: What four countries have the red fire ant most notably invaded successfully and have established a strong foothold in?\n
Question 10: What organism is one of the only natural predators of the red fire ant?
A. Pouring vinegar over the mound
B. Placing cyanide dust on the mound
C. There is no effective way to control fire ant mounds
D. Pouring hot boiling water onto the mound
B. United States, Australia, China, Taiwan
D. United States, South Korea, Mexico, Dominican Republic

string.name: instructions
string.i: Instructions: Select the best answer for each question. Click the submit button when you are finished to have your quiz graded.

resources.string: Hint: You can zoom in and out by using the standard touchscreen pinch in and out gestures or by using the zoom in and out controls that appear when you start to scroll\n
